errors.error_description: In the example code, `tune_params` is incorrectly formatted as a list of tuples instead of a dictionary, which will cause a syntax or type error in the `tune_kernel` function.
correction_candidates: tune_params = {'block_size_x': [32, 64, 128, 256, 512]}
tune_params = dict(block_size_x=[32, 64, 128, 256, 512])
tune_params = "block_size_x: [32, 64, 128, 256, 512]"

errors.error_description: The installation steps are in the wrong logical order. The `pip install` command is listed before the instruction to install the prerequisite CUDA/OpenCL/HIP compilers, which could cause the installation to fail or the package to not find the necessary backend.
correction_candidates: Swap the first two bullet points in the 'Installation' section so that compiler installation comes before the `pip install` command.
The `pip install` command will automatically install the required compilers.
The order does not matter as the package will prompt for compiler location on first run.
Combine the two steps into one command: `install-compilers && pip install kernel_tuner[...]`
errors.golden_answer: Swap the first two bullet points in the 'Installation' section so that compiler installation comes before the `pip install` command.

errors.error_description: The hyperlink for the 'Getting Started' guide in the Resources section points to a non-existent page (`quick_start.html` instead of `quickstart.html`), resulting in a 404 error.
correction_candidates: Change the link URL to `https://kerneltuner.github.io/kernel_tuner/stable/quickstart.html`.
Change the link URL to `https://kerneltuner.github.io/kernel_tuner/stable/getting_started.html`.
Remove the link as the documentation is deprecated.
Change the link URL to `https://kerneltuner.github.io/kernel_tuner/latest/quickstart.html`.

errors.error_description: The installation instructions incorrectly state that the package requires Python 2.7, which is outdated and incompatible with modern scientific Python packages. This will likely cause installation or runtime errors.
correction_candidates: Remove the line 'Note: This package requires Python 2.7.'
Change the line to 'Note: This package requires Python 3.6 or newer.'
The package is compatible with both Python 2 and 3.
Use `pip2` to install the package for Python 2.7.
errors.golden_answer: Remove the line 'Note: This package requires Python 2.7.'

errors.error_description: In the example, the kernel name passed to `tune_kernel` is 'vector_add_kernel', but the kernel defined in the string is named 'vector_add'. This mismatch will cause an error when the tuner tries to find the kernel.
correction_candidates: Change the first argument of `tune_kernel` from 'vector_add_kernel' to 'vector_add'.
Rename the kernel in the kernel string to `__global__ void vector_add_kernel(...)`.
Pass the kernel name as a keyword argument: `tune_kernel(kernel_name='vector_add', ...)`
The kernel name is optional and can be removed from the function call.
errors.golden_answer: Change the first argument of `tune_kernel` from 'vector_add_kernel' to 'vector_add'.

errors.error_description: The README includes a misleading statement that Kernel Tuner 'Automatically rewrites your Python code into optimized CUDA C++,' which is not a feature of the tool and will confuse users about its core functionality.
correction_candidates: Remove the bullet point: '- Automatically rewrites your Python code into optimized CUDA C++'
Clarify that this feature is experimental and must be enabled with a special flag.
Change the statement to 'Works with tools like Numba or CuPy to transpile Python'.
This feature is only available in the enterprise version of Kernel Tuner.
errors.golden_answer: Remove the bullet point: '- Automatically rewrites your Python code into optimized CUDA C++'

errors.error_description: The `pip install` command uses the incorrect package name `kernel-tuner` (with a hyphen) instead of the correct `kernel_tuner` (with an underscore), which will cause the installation to fail with a 'package not found' error.
correction_candidates: Replace all instances of `kernel-tuner` with `kernel_tuner` in the `pip install` commands.
Use quotes around the package name: `pip install 'kernel-tuner[cuda]'`.
The package was renamed; both `kernel-tuner` and `kernel_tuner` are valid aliases.
Use conda, as it correctly resolves the package name: `conda install kernel-tuner`.
errors.golden_answer: Replace all instances of `kernel-tuner` with `kernel_tuner` in the `pip install` commands.
